Welcome to the FrogLab You are now a researcher interested in frog genetics. Particularly, you are interested in how different features are inherited in a new tropical frog species. The problem: This frog species includes several color morphs (i.e., variations in colors and patterns), which have evolved in response to sexual selection and to scare away predators. Since it is a novel species, we don\'t know anything about how the different aspects of coloration are transmitted to the next generation. Fig. 1: Two individuals with different coloration patterns. Your goals: In order to understand the inheritance of color patterns in this species, you will pursue the following specific goals: \tGoal #1: Learn how each trait is inherited (i.e., autosomal recessive, linked to sex, etc). \tGoal #2: Learn how many loci are involved in coloration patterns. \tGoal #3: Study linkage between loci and build a genetic map comprising the relative positions of all of them in the different chromosomes. Fig. 2: Genetic map of an arm of one of the fruit fly chromosomes.
How to do it: Like in all Genetics laboratories, your methodology will consist in crossing frogs (a female and a male) and look at the progeny. Over time, your crossing strategy and your understanding of genetics will improve. Don\'t forget your lab notebook to take track of all your experiments! We don\'t do it for you. In the laboratory there are Individual cards and Family cards. Fig. 3: Individual card. Fig. 4: Family card. Two individual cards can be selected to create a new Family. By pressing the top-right icons you can also save a frog to the Database (for instance, if, after several crossings, you obtain an interesting frog which you might want to use in future crossings) or export a .png picture of it. Each time you set up a crossing, a new family card is created displaying the images and IDs of the two parents. Right under the Family card, the new offspring cards are shown. NOTE: You can\'t set up crossings with individuals from different families. This is bad laboratory practice. Frog nomenclature: > The Frog ID (for instance, F2.5.38) is composed of three elements: the generation (F2), the family number (5) and the individual number (38). By convention, the generation of parental individuals is named "P0", and the subsequent offspring generations are named "F1", "F2", etc. > Options Menu: For Goal#1 you can use Difficulty Level 1 or Level 2. In these modes only alleles affecting the same feature segregate at the same time, so it is easier to draw conclusions. For Goal#2 and Goal#3 you should use Level 3 and Map Mode. Research in genetics can be tough. You can turn the Cheating Option on to be able to see the frog genotypes. However, we encourage you to use this option only after having played for a while, in order to check that you are right about your discoveries. This is an open problem game, so we don\'t provide solutions otherwise. Good Luck! Carlos Mora 2021
